cab.content: THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OP HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENTPrinted for the Cabinet. March 1936.SECRET. Copy No.CP. 78 (36).CABINET.EGYPT : PROTECTION OF FOREIGNERS. 1 Note by the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs. I CIRCULATE to my colleagues a copy (Annex I) of a telegram from His-Majesty's High Commissioner in Cairo dealing with the suggestion that, besidesincluding in the proposed Anglo-Egyptian Treaty an article in the terms ofarticle 3 of the 1930 Draft Treaty (Annex II) an addition should be made to anarticle in the terms of article 7 of the 1930 draft (Annex III) to the following effect : " The high contracting parties would also consult together if circum- stances should arise involving the possibility of any intervention into the: internal affairs of Egypt by any third Power." Sir M. Lampson's telegram tends to show that His Majesty's government cannot hope to secure from the Egyptian Government on this point undertakings in any appreciable degree greater than those contained in article 3 of the 1930Draft Treaty. At the same time, I consider that, if His Majesty's Governmentinsist on an article in the same terms as article 3 and limit their insistence tothis, there is justification for expecting that they could secure it on this occasiontoo. I would therefore once more urge my colleagues to accept article 3 of the1930 draft without addition. If, nevertheless, my colleagues do not feel able to agree to this course, therewould, judging from Sir M. Lampson's telegram, be no serious objection to^attempting to secure Egyptian agreement to the suggested addition to an article in the terms of article 7 of the 1930 draft. As regards the suggestion in the last sentence of the High Commissioner^telegram, I consider that His Majesty's Government should refuse to accept anytext weaker than article 3 of the 1930 draft and, unless the chance of securing'something stronger should unexpectedly present itself, should insist on retaining the same text as in 1930. A. E. Foreign Office, March 14, 1936.8473 [12898][ANNEX I. ANNEX I. Sir M. Lampson to Mr. Eden.(No. 214.)(Telegraphic.) Cairo, March 11, 1936. YOUR telegram No. 131. We all here feel that proposed addition is really superfluous. But that, ifthe idea is to be pursued, proposal formula in your telegram is, prima facie, agood one. 2. It seems to me that by putting it at the end of article 7 of 1930 draftit should be more easily acceptable by the Egyptian side. But we must alwaysremember that we ourselves having formally refused to admit the principle that.a draft unsuccessfully negotiated necessarily applies later (Egyptians may noweasily jib at the wording of article 3 of 1930 draft regulations, which was onlywrung from them with the greatest difficulty). Four of the present Egyptiannegotiators are the same men as in 1930; and will thus be personally aware of points on which they then gave way. It follows that we cannot now bank on egyptian side necessarily agreeing to the same terms in any article that theydid in 1930.ANNEX II. Article 3 of the Draft Treaty of 1930. HIS Britannic Majesty recognises that the responsibility for the lives andpropert)' of foreigners in Egypt devolves exclusively upon the Egyptian Govern-ment, who will ensure the fulfilment of their obligations in this respect.ANNEX III. Article 7 of the Draft Treaty of 1930. SHOULD any dispute with a third State produce a situation which involves a risk of a rupture with that State, the high contracting parties will consulteach other with a view to the settlement of the said dispute by peaceful means,in accordance with the provisions of the Covenant of the League of Nations andof any other international obligations which may be applicable to the case.
